  1. Developer Center ↩ ↩2

entry.title: Sentry
entry.summary: Sentry IO is a robust error tracking and monitoring platform for developers. It helps identify, prioritize, and resolve issues in software applications by capturing real-time error data, providing detailed insights into their causes, and enabling efficient collaboration among development teams. With its user-friendly interface and integrations, Sentry IO enhances software quality and user experience by facilitating proactive error management.Identities ❌ | Accounts ✔️ | Groups ✔️ | App Roles ✔️ | Entitlements ❌
entry.content:
Sentry IO is a robust error tracking and monitoring platform for developers. It helps identify, prioritize, and resolve issues in software applications by capturing real-time error data, providing detailed insights into their causes, and enabling efficient collaboration among development teams. With its user-friendly interface and integrations, Sentry IO enhances software quality and user experience by facilitating proactive error management.

Identities ❌ | Accounts ✔️ | Groups ✔️ | App Roles ✔️ | Entitlements ❌

Users are individuals who have access to the Sentry platform. Each user has a unique account and can be assigned specific roles and permissions that determine their level of access and actions they can perform within the organization. Users can be developers, administrators, or other team members involved in monitoring and resolving issues.

Teams are groups of users who collaborate on specific projects and share responsibilities. A team typically represents a functional unit within the organization, such as a development team, operations team, or customer support team. Teams help manage access control, streamline communication, and group users with similar responsibilities together.

Projects are individual software applications, services, or components that you want to monitor and track for errors and issues. Each project represents a unique codebase or software entity. Errors and events related to a project are collected, analyzed, and presented within the context of that project. Projects can belong to one or more teams, depending on the organizational structure.

Relationships between these components:

  • Users and Teams: Users belong to one or more teams. This association helps define which projects a user can access and what actions they can perform within those projects. Teams provide a way to manage user access and collaboration efficiently.

  • Teams and Projects: Teams can be assigned to one or more projects. This allows multiple teams to work on different aspects of a project or collaborate on multiple projects simultaneously. Teams define who has access to specific projects and contribute to error tracking and resolution efforts.

  • Users and Projects: Users who belong to teams associated with a project can access and work on that project. They can view error reports, manage issues, and collaborate with other team members to address software problems.

Application​

Steps

  1. Login to RSA G&L console as System Administrator.
  2. Navigate to Resources > Application.
  3. Click on Create Application and select Other Application.
  4. Enter the details as shown below.
  5. Click Finish.

Account Collector​

This section explains the process for configuring an account collector for the Sentry application. We will use the RSA G&L Generic REST collector 1 for this purpose.

caution

G&L does not support the cursor based pagination model used by Sentry. For more information, refer to Paginating Results

  2. Navigate to Resources > Applications.
  3. Click on Sentry.
  4. Navigate to Collectors tab and click on Create Account Collector. Enter the details as shown below.

  5. Click Next and enter the connection details.

  6. Click Next. Select the data types that the collector will be collecting from Sentry

  7. Click Next. On the Account Data page, enter the following configurations.

URL/organizations/ORG_SLUG/members/ (Replace ORG_SLUG with your organization SLUG)
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
AccountId$.*.email
Id$.*.id
IsActive$.*.user.isActive
lastLogin$.*.user.lastLogin
  1. Click Next. On the Group Data page, enter the following configurations.



Request
MethodGET
URL/organizations/ORG_SLUG/teams/ (Replace ORG_SLUG with your organization SLUG)
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
GroupId$.*.slug
Id$.*.id
  1. Click Next. On the Account Group Membership page, enter the following configurations.



Request
MethodGET
URL/teams/ORG_SLUG/${GroupId}/members/ (Replace ORG_SLUG with your organization SLUG)
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
Account Identifier$.*.id
  1. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to Account Attributes, map the collected account attributes.

  2. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to Account Mapping Attributes, map the user reference attribute.

  3. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to Group Attributes, map the collected group attributes.

  4. Click Next. In the User Resolution Rules, map the user to account.

  5. Click Next. In the Member Account Resolution Rules, map the account.

💡 Info: This value MUST always be mapped to the Account Name for any generic REST collector.

  1. Click Finish. Use the Test function to make sure the configurations are accurate.

Entitlement Collector​

Roles​

This section explains the process for configuring an entitlement collector to collect roles and assignments to users from Sentry application. We will use the RSA G&L Generic REST collector 1 for this purpose.

caution

G&L does not support the cursor based pagination model used by Sentry. For more information, refer to Paginating Results

  5. Click Next and enter the connection details as shown in Step 5 of Account Collector.
  6. Click Next. Select the data types that the collector will be collecting from Sentry.

  7. Click Next. On the App Role Data page, enter the following configurations.

Response Mappings

Request

  1. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to App Role Attributes, map the collected account attributes.

  2. Click Next. In the Account Evaluation, map the account collector to account value.

  3. Click Next and then click Finish. Use the Test function to make sure the configurations are accurate.

Projects​

This section explains the process for configuring an entitlement collector to collect projects as roles and its assignments to teams from the Sentry application. We will use the RSA G&L Generic REST collector 1 for this purpose.

caution

G&L does not support the cursor based pagination model used by Sentry. For more information, refer to Paginating Results

  3. Click on Sentry.
  4. Navigate to Collectors tab and click on Create Entitlement Collector. Enter the details as shown below.

  5. Click Next and enter the connection details as shown in Step 5 of Account Collector.
  6. Click Next. Select the data types that the collector will be collecting from Sentry.

  7. Click Next. On the App Role Data page, enter the following configurations.



Request
MethodGET
URL/projects/
Request Headers

AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings

Id$.*.platform
Description$.*.id
  1. Click Next. On the App-Role Group Membership collection page, enter the following configurations.



Request
MethodGET
URL/projects/ORG_SLUG/${ApplicationRoleId}/ (Replace ORG_SLUG with your organization SLUG)
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
Group Identifier$.teams.*.id
  1. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to App Role Attributes, map the collected account attributes.

  2. Click Next. In the Account Evaluation, map the account collector to account value.

  3. Click Next and then click Finish. Use the Test function to make sure the configurations are accurate.

Application Setup​

This section explains the process of setting up Sentry for integration with G&L. Sentry API calls require application key and API key for most invocations.

  2. Go to Settings and then select Custom Integrations under Developer Settings.

  3. Click on Create New Integration. Select Internal Integration as the type and click Next.

  4. Provide a suitable name and permissions as shown below. Click Save Changes.

  5. Copy the token value.

COL042

entry.title: Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD)
entry.summary: Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) is Microsoft's cloud-based identity and access
entry.content:
Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) is Microsoft's cloud-based identity and access management service. It provides secure authentication, single sign-on, and identity protection for applications, devices, and users across the cloud and on-premises environments. Entra ID enhances security and productivity through centralized management, seamless collaboration, and adaptive access controls, making it an essential component for modern businesses.

Identities ✔️ | Accounts ✔️ | Groups ✔️ | App Roles ✔️ | Entitlements ❌


Versions: 7.5.2 P08 8.0.0 P1

note

We will refer to Entra ID as Azure AD interchangeably

Users in Entra ID represent individuals who have access to resources within the organization's Entra ID tenant. Each user has a unique identity and associated credentials (username and password) to authenticate themselves and gain access to various applications and services. Users can be added manually or synchronized from an on-premises directory using Entra ID Connect.

Groups are containers that simplify the management of user access and permissions. Instead of assigning permissions to individual users, you can assign them to a group, and all members of that group inherit those permissions. Groups can be created to represent departments, project teams, or any logical grouping of users.

Group Members are the users associated with a specific group. Users can be added as members of one or more groups, which allows them to inherit the access and permissions granted to those groups. When a user is added to or removed from a group, their access and permissions are automatically updated based on the group's configuration. Group members can be individual users, other groups (nested groups), or even service principals (identities used by applications).

Directory Roles define the level of access and permissions that can be assigned to users or groups within the Entra ID tenant. These roles are predefined and have specific permissions associated with them.

Member Users and Groups refer to the entities that are assigned roles and granted permissions within Entra ID.

Performance Considerations
  • Use the $select to bring in only the required data elements thereby reducing the volume of data in the REST API response. This will also result in smaller number of pages in the result set.
  • Use $filter to reduce the data set if you need only a subset of data hereby reducing the volume of data in the REST API response. This will also result in smaller number of pages in the result set. Use $expand sparingly as it can result in longer response times as well as larger data volume. If using $expand use the $select to filter out unwanted data elements.

Application​

Steps

  1. Login to RSA G&L console as System Administrator.
  2. Navigate to Resources > Application.
  3. Click on Create Application and select Other Directory.
  4. Enter the details as shown below.
  5. Click Finish.

Identity Collector​

This section explains the process for configuring an identity collector for the Entra ID application. We will use the RSA G&L generic REST collector for this purpose.

Steps

  1. Login to RSA G&L console as System Administrator.
  2. Navigate to Resources > Applications.
  3. Click on Entra ID.
  4. Navigate to Collectors tab and click on Create Identity Collector. Enter the details as shown below.

  5. Click Next and enter the connection details.



    If authentication type is OAuth2, refer to OAuth2 Configuration section.
    If authentication type is Token, refer to Token Configuration section.

  6. Click Next. On the User Data page, enter the following configurations.




    Request
    MethodGET
    URL/users
    Query Parameters
    $selectid,givenName,surname,jobTitle,userPrincipalName,mail,officeLocation,companyName
    Request Headers
    Acceptapplication/json
    AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
    Response Mappings
    UserId$.value[*].userPrincipalName
    Id$.value[*].id
    FirstName$.value[*].givenName
    LastName$.value[*].surname
    Email$.value[*].mail
    Title$.value[*].title
  7. Click Next. On the Map Collector Attributes to User Attributes page, enter the following configurations.




  8. Click Finish. Use the Test function to make sure the configurations are accurate.

Account Collector​

This section explains the process for configuring an account collector for the Entra ID application. We will use the RSA G&L Generic REST collector for this purpose.

Steps

  1. Login to RSA G&L console as System Administrator.
  2. Navigate to Resources > Applications.
  3. Click on Entra ID.
  4. Navigate to Collectors tab and click on Create Account Collector. Enter the details as shown below.

  5. Click Next and enter the connection details as shown in Step 5 of Identity Collector.
  6. Click Next. Select the data types that the collector will be collecting from Entra ID

  7. Click Next. On the Account Data page, enter the following configurations.




    Request
    MethodGET
    URLusers
    Request Headers
    Acceptapplication/json
    AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
    Response Mappings
    AccountId$.value[*].userPrincipalName
    Id$.value[*].id

  8. Click Next. On the Group Data page, enter the following configurations.




note

Here, the $expand query parameter can be optionally passed to collect the group owners information

Request
MethodGET
URLgroups
Query Parameters
$selectid,displayName,description
$expandowners($select=displayName,userPrincipalName,employeeId)
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
GroupId$.value[*].displayName
Id$.value[*].id
Description$.value[*].description
Owner$.value.*.owners[*].employeeId
  1. Click Next. On the Account Group Membership page, enter the following configurations.




    Request
    MethodGET
    URLgroups/${Id}/members
    Query Parameters
    $selectid,userPrincipalName
    Request Headers
    Acceptapplication/json
    AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
    Response Mappings
    Account Identifier$.value[*].id
  2. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to Account Attributes, map the collected account attributes.

  3. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to Account Mapping Attributes, map the user reference attribute.

  4. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to Group Attributes, map the collected group attributes.

  5. Click Next. In the User Resolution Rules, map the user to account.

  6. Click Next. In the Member Account Resolution Rules, map the account.

💡 Info: This value MUST always be mapped to the Account Name for any generic REST collector.

  1. Click Finish. Use the Test function to make sure the configurations are accurate.

Entitlement Collector​

This section explains the process for configuring an entitlement collector to collect safes from Entra ID application. We will use the RSA G&L Generic REST collector for this purpose.

Steps

  1. Login to RSA G&L console as AveksaAdmin.
  2. Navigate to Resources > Applications.
  3. Click on Entra ID.
  4. Navigate to Collectors tab and click on Create Entitlement Collector. Enter the details as shown below.

  5. Click Next and enter the connection details as shown in Step 5 of Identity Collector.
  6. Click Next. Select the data types that the collector will be collecting from Entra ID.

  7. Click Next. On the App Role Data page, enter the following configurations.



Pagination

This API does not support pagination

Request
MethodGET
URLdirectoryRoles
Query Parameters
$selectid,displayName,description
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
ApplicationRoleId$.value.*.displayName
Id$.value.*.id
Description$.value.*.description
  1. Click Next. On the App-Role Account Membership collection page, enter the following configurations.



Pagination

This API does not support pagination

Request
MethodGET
URLdirectoryRoles/${Id}/members/microsoft.graph.user
Query Parameters
$selectid,userPrincipalName,mail
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
Account Identifier$.value.*.id
  1. Click Next. On the App-Role Group Membership collection page, enter the following configurations.



Pagination

This API does not support pagination

Request
MethodGET
URLdirectoryRoles/${Id}/members/microsoft.graph.group
Query Parameters
$selectid,displayName,description
Request Headers
Acceptapplication/json
AuthorizationBearer ${AuthenticationToken}
Response Mappings
Group Identifier$.value.*.displayName
  1. Click Next. In the Map Collector Attributes to App Role Attributes, map the collected account attributes.

  2. Click Next. In the Account Evaluation, map the account collector to account value.

  3. Click Next. In the Group Evaluation, map the account collector to group value.

  4. Click Next and then click Finish. Use the Test function to make sure the configurations are accurate.

Application Setup​

Azure App​

This section explains the setup of credentials for the service account that will be used with RSA G&L ADC and EDC.

Steps

  1. Login to Azure portal, Microsoft Azure
  2. Select Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD).

  3. Note down the Tenant ID. This is required in the RSA G&L collector configuration.

  4. Click on App Registrations.

  5. Click on New Registration
  6. Provide the details as shown below. Under Redirect URI, provide OAuth callback URL (https://instance.com:8443/aveksa/oauth/callback) for RSA G&L.

  7. Click Register.
  8. Note down the Client ID. This is required in the RSA G&L collector configuration.
  9. Click on View API Permissions.

  10. Select Microsoft Graph.

  11. Select Application Permissions.

  12. Select the below permissions.



Permissions

Some suggested permissions (you may need more if you are collecting additional data)

User.Read.AllRead user data
Group.Read.AllRead group definitions
GroupMember.Read.AllRead group membership data
RoleManagement.Read.AllFor collecting role definitions and role assignments
  1. Click Add Permissions.
  2. Click on Certificates & Secrets. Click on New Client Secret.

  3. Set the Description and suitable expiration period for the client secret.
  4. Click Add. Note down the Client Secret which will be displayed only once. This is required for the RSA G&L collector configuration.

Admin Consent​

Steps

  1. Refer to Authorization and the Microsoft Graph Security API - Microsoft Graph | Microsoft Docs for information on Admin consent.
  2. Prepare the Admin Consent URL as shown below and send it to the M365 administrator to consent.
Format:

https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/adminconsent?client_id=<Application Id>&state=12345&redirect_uri=<Redirect URL>

Example:
https://login.microsoftonline.com/a6d53c2-0f80-4a2e-947e-2a6h324jg1b71/adminconsent?client_id=24fsdfb1-8b66-4ba9-8f21-a7casdf73b1&state=4534646&redirect_uri=https://igl.company.com:8443/aveksa/oauth/callback
  1. Once the Admin clicks the URL, they must login and authorize.

Authentication​

OAuth2​

This section explains the process of setting up RSA G&L ADC with OAuth2 authentication.

Steps

  1. Login to RSA G&L console as System Administrator.
  2. Create or Edit a generic REST ADC that will be using OAuth2 authentication.
  3. On the Connection Details page, configure the following.


    Request
    Client IDThe Application (client) ID
    Client SecretThe client secret
    Authentication URLhttps://login.microsoftonline.com/YOUR_TENANT_ID/oauth2/v2.0/authorize
    Access Token URLhttps://login.microsoftonline.com/YOUR_TENANT_ID/oauth2/v2.0/token
    Scopeopenid offline_access
  4. Click on Get OAuth 2.0 Access Token.
  5. Click on Proceed For Authorization.

  6. Login to Microsoft with the appropriate account credentials.

  7. The below message indicates that RSA G&L has successfully acquired a token.

  8. Click Close.
  9. Save the collector configuration. Use the Test function to make sure the configurations are accurate.

Token​

This section explains the process of setting up RSA G&L ADC and EDC with token authentication from Microsoft Graph.

Steps

  1. Login to RSA G&L console as System Administrator.
  2. Create or Edit a generic REST ADC or EDC that will be using Token authentication.
  3. On the Connection Details page, configure the following.


    Request
    MethodPOST
    Token URLhttps://login.microsoftonline.com/TENANT_ID/oauth2/v2.0/token
    UsernameClient ID
    PasswordClient Secret
    Request Headers
    Acceptapplication/json
    Content-Typeapplication/x-www-form-urlencoded
    Request Body
    grant_type=client_credentials&client_id=${TokenUsername}&
    client_secret=${TokenPassword}&scope=https://graph.microsoft.com/.default
    Response Mappings
    Response Path$.access_token
  4. Save the collector configuration & test.
